awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Multi-functional and Multi-Material Additive Nanomanufacturing: Acoustic Field-Assisted Stereolithography (AFS)
awd_abstract_narration:
The successful development of nanomachines is pivotal for the realization of future intelligent nanorobots, nanofactories, and nanomedicine. Through applications in nano and micro surgery, targeted drug delivery, and environmental pollutant removal, the impact of nanomachines on every aspect of daily lives as well as the global economy is expected to be significant. However, the manufacturing of nanomachines is challenging due to the difficulty in combining multiple materials or assembling multiple components into a three-dimensional structure to achieve the desired functionalities. Most currently reported nano and micromachines are limited to very simple designs with spherical or cylindrical geometries and thus limited functions, while requiring a large amount of labor, time, and cost for fabrication. This award investigates the scalable and efficient manufacturing of multi-material three-dimensional objects consisting of arbitrarily distributed nano-sized building-blocks. The project studies the advent of multi-functionality by nanoparticle localization through patterning and building 3D objects by solidifying particle-polymer suspensions layer-by-layer. Furthermore, this research advances knowledge of multi-material structure design and development, and paves the way for a new scientific paradigm for the design, fabrication, and application of multi-functional nanomachines. Course modules on additive nanomanufacturing are planned for education in engineering both at the two collaborative universities and at local middle and high schools. Special attention is given to encourage the participation of women, persons with disabilities, and traditionally underrepresented groups. 

Current manufacturing methods for nanomachines are limited by scalability, efficiency, and material and geometric diversity. To overcome these constraints, this project aims to establish a new additive nanomanufacturing strategy for fabricating 3D multi-material particle-polymer nanocomposites, and to test the hypothesis that the localized nanoparticle distribution can produce multi-functionalities. The research approach -- acoustic field-assisted stereolithography -- utilizes an acoustic field to pattern nanoparticles with macro-to-nano scale resolutions and build a 3D object by solidifying the particle-polymer suspensions layer-by-layer. This research integrates multiple physical phenomena with nanomanufacturing and involves various disciplines of science and engineering including modeling and simulation, process design and development, material and device characterization. This project contributes to advances in additive nanomanufacturing, nanotechnology, and innovations in nanomaterials and nanomachines.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: IOWA STATE UNIVERSITY OF SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY

por.por_cntn:
The successful development of functional polymer composites is pivotal for the realization of future intelligent devices and structures. It will make huge impacts on every aspect of our daily lives as well as the global economy, through applications in energy, medicine, sustainability, and the even greater number of potential applications that have yet to be discovered. However, the manufacturing of functional polymer composites is still challenging due to the difficulty in combining multiple materials or assembling multiple components into a 3D structure to achieve desired functionalities. Most currently reported composites have random and homogeneous distribution of constituent materials and thus limited functions.

This project establishes a new additive nanomanufacturing strategy for fabricating 3D multi-material particle-polymer nanocomposites by using an acoustic field to control the 3D distribution of particles in the polymer matrix. The resulting localized nanoparticle distribution enables novel functionalities, which was exemplified by a composite surface structure with locally engineered water wettability for highly efficient water vapor harvesting. This project also successfully developed a computationally cheap physics-informed machine learning (PIML) model for the acoustic assisted particle pattering process. The PIML model can effectively predict the particle patterns given by a high-fidelity but computationally expensive multiphysics model while running about 16000 times faster than the physics model.

This project provides a scalable method to manufacture composites with highly localized properties that is impossible with current techniques. The research results uphold the research hypothesis that the controlling the local distribution of nanoparticles in the matrix produces new functionalities in the resulting composite materials. This project contributes to the research in the design, manufacturing and application of next-generation composite materials by generating new fundamental knowledge on structure-property/functionality relationship in these materials. The discoveries of this project will promote the development of new composite materials, such as heterogeneous nanocomposites, functionally graded nanomaterials, complicated 3D nanomachine designs, advanced nano- or micro- sensors/actuators, etc. This project also establishes a framework for combining physics and data science to develop effective and efficient process model, which paves the way for high-throughput manufacturing process design and optimization. 

The established capability to manufacture multi-material structures, with controlled distribution of constituent materials, scalable build size, and high efficiency, will make huge impacts on our daily lives as well as global economy. For example, the water harvesting composite structure fabricated by the acoustic assisted method could be a viable tool for environmental engineers to solve rural and urban water issues around the globe. Although this project mainly focuses on the model system of nanoparticle-polymer composite, the developed process and knowledge could be transferred to biological cell and polymer composites, which will benefit research that requires the strategic allocation of cells in a polymer matrix in 3D space, for applications in tissue engineering, regenerative medicine, organ-on-a-chip, etc. 

This project offered a wide range of education and outreach programs, including 1) it provides trainings, research experiences, and professional development opportunities to participating undergraduate and graduate students on the areas of additive manufacturing, composite materials, acoustics and vibration, multiphysics modeling and simulation, machine learning and data sciences. 2) it incorporates research findings into the composite materials and manufacturing curriculum, 3) it broadens the participation in Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (STEM) by the PI's participation in the outreach activities at the "Go Further: Girls STEM Conference", which showcases women as workforce in STEM to girls in grade 8-10, 4) it contributes to increase rural community's access to STEM education resources by supporting the PI and students' efforts on developing and presenting hands-on science activities during the "Boone Family STEM Festival" in Boone, Iowa.


Last Modified: 11/17/2022
Modified by: Shan Hu
